title: Chicago Fed National Activity Index Points to Slower Economic Growth in September
text:
By Patrick Thomas

The Chicago Fed National Activity Index, a measure of economic activity in the U.S., went into negative territory in September after it ticked up above zero in August.

For September, the index was negative 0.45, down from positive 0.15 the month before. The Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago said all four broad categories that comprise the index decreased from August, and all four categories made negative contributions to the index in September.

Production-related indicators contributed negative 0.37 in September, down from positive 0.19 in August. Industrial production declined 0.4% after rising 0.8% in August. The sales, orders and inventories category ticked down to negative 0.02 from negative 0.01 in August.

Employment-related indicators contributed negative 0.02 in September, up slightly from negative 0.03 in August. Total nonfarm payrolls increased by 136,000 in September after rising by 168,000 in the previous month.

Eighty-five indicators make up the index, and of those, 31 positively contributed and 54 negatively contributed. A total of 29 of the 85 indicators improved from the prior month, while 54 deteriorated and two were unchanged, the Chicago Fed said.

The index's three-month moving average, CFNAI-MA3, decreased to negative 0.24 in September from negative 0.06 in August.

Write to Patrick Thomas at patrick.thomas@wsj.com

(END) Dow Jones Newswires

October 28, 2019 08:44 ET (12:44 GMT)
